text:
SUE MI TERRY: When
Mr. Trump also

had made a kind of
faux pas when he said,

he mentioned that he
learn from Xi Jin Ping

that South Korea
was part of China.

And that got South Korean
public quite riled up.

AMARA WALKER: And I want
to ask you about that.

I mean, I know you were born
and raised in South Korea.

And you know I'm
Korean-American myself.

And we know that this is
a very explosive, very
sensitive issue for Koreans.

Because what Trump
said was totally false.
It was incorrect.

Not sure if that was some
kind of misunderstanding.
SUE MI TERRY: Totally false.

- It's what he was told.
He just believed it.

AMARA WALKER: But
this underscores.
And he just kind of-- exactly.

Or perhaps he didn't
understand the story correctly.

But I mean, tell us more about
why this is so offensive.

SUE MI TERRY:
Well, first of all,

South Korea is very
sensitive about its history

and territorial ambitions
of China and Japan

because the Korean peninsula has
been invaded by both countries.

But Korea, the Korean peninsula
has never been a part of China.

So Mr. Trump saying that he
learned from Xi Jing Ping

in a 10-minute conversation the
history of the Korean peninsula
is problematic.
And it's wrong information.

So it just shows how little
President Trump actually
knows about the Korean history.
And this is very inaccurate.

And I think the Korean
public has every right
to be quite upset about this.

AMARA WALKER: And it
underscores Trump's ignorance to
these kinds of sensitivities.

And the fact that history
depends on who you ask, right?
SUE MI TERRY: Absolutely right.

AMARA WALKER: On
their perspective.
- That's a very good point.
